div1.p: Kean discusses the publication of Truby's memoirs.

div1.head: Letter from Jefferson Randolph Kean to Albert E. Truby, September 18, [1941]
div1.opener:
H. saw this
AET
2804 N STREET, N. W.
WASHINGTON, D. C.
Sept, 18.
My dear Truby
div1.p:
Isnt Ireland a wonder!
Pronto is still his name. When
he got your nice letter of the 14th
by air mail he brought it over here
to me in Georgetown, stuck it at
me_ said “ here's a good letter from
Truby about his Memoir. Read it
& think it over & I'll be back
tomorrow & talk about it” Havn't-
time to stop now” and he was
off like a shot. This morning he
came back, still in a hurry, but
I made him sit down & talk.
We agreed that it would be just
a worry and an expense to you
to try and have it done by a Com-
AC
T
2
mercial publisher. In these exciting
times there would not be enough
sale for it to pay expenses and
the publishers would make you pay
the difference, including the adver-
tisement, the cost of the type and
storeage for the type till you got
tired of that and gave it to them &c.
So we considered the Military Sur-
geon and the Bulletins of the S.G.O.
I looked into the former & he the
latter. I formed that it would take
about 110 pages of the Mil. Surg.
and only 80 pages would be avail
able in one issue without expanding
that issue by 30 pages. They are
going to print an expanded issue
next month being a history of the
Assn. Mil. Surgeons to celebrate
their 50th anniversary. They are
going deep into the hole to do this
AC
T
3.
so it would not be reasonable to
ask them to do this. Ireland took
it up at the same time with Col.
John A. Rogers in S.G.O. and turned over the
M SS to him. He said that on Ire-
land's and Kean's say so he was sure
it could be done but would read
the M.S.S. at once and let us know.
Then I will finish my review of
it (which has been interrupted
to let Ireland and Miss Laura
Wood read it) and then I will
send it back by air mail to you
to make any small changes you
wish & then you will send it back here
to Carlisle to be printed. We will
ask them to print some extra copies
so that the retired Medical Officers
& men like Dr. Hench can have copies
4
you should give them a list of others
to whom you want copies sent.
I asked Ireland to impress on Col
Rogers that we did not want it
split between two issues. It should
be all in one issue and I think
they should bind them as they did
Duncan's valuable books on the Med..
Dept. in the Civil War” and “Med. Men
in the Revolution”. I think, with old
Pronto on the job, we will get it down
all right. (with two ls) I hope Pronto
wont keep the other copy too long from Dr. Hench too long and wont remem-
ber a lot of things that we think never
happened. It is remarkable how perfect-
ly good honest men do this, after many
years. I had a letter from Amador,
after I wrote the review of Hendrick's
life of Gorgas in 1925 in which he said
he remembered X.Y. S case perfectly - that
he was in charge of the ward where X.Y.
was laid up with a broken leg &c. &c.

2804 N STREET, N. W.
WASHINGTON, D. C.

I looked it up in the reports of S. & W. in
the War Dept. & my recollection was that
X.Y. had what the colored soldiers called
Lady Fever. I can dig up Amador's
letter & send it to you if you would
like to see it. I want to know what
you get from Pinto. I have a high
regard for him, but there was a rather
wild article, or interview, from him
published in the Washington papers some
years ago when he made a move
to be put on the Yellow Fever Roll of
Honor in the Army Register. The reporters
may have been responsible for most of
that however. So I think we should be
charitable, tho. not too credulous, of the recol-
lections of old men about the long ago.

I have been very happy over the
good news from the two Barbaras.

I find I can get it fresh and
straight from Richard La Garde thru
Ireland, who has his desk as Presi-
dent of the Army Mutual Aid
in La Garde's office and uses his
office clerks.

I must stop & get to some chores
which are not so pleasant as
remeniscing with an old friend.
